poem:
**Election Morning**

In the pale light  
of November—  
a leaf tilts,  
undecided in wind—  
as the pulse  
of the city hums—  
a throaty call  
echoes,  
urging silence  
to listen,  
as voices,  
not yet gathered,  
prepare to pen  
their whispered choice  
in ink,  
hope curling  
like smoke  
from chimneys  
full of winter's breath.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Americans who believe in democracy have no choice but to vote for Harris | Observer editorial ‘It ain’t over ’til the fat lady sings” – that well-known if dated American sporting adage – may afford Kamala Harris a little comfort in the final, testing days leading up to the US presidential election on 5 November. The contest is too close to call. That has been the case for weeks, if not months. The latest national". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
